Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Origin of Persistent Organic Pollutants in the Antarctic Atmosphere, Snow and Marine Food WEB
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many persistent organic pollutants (POPs), though banned in the U.S. since the 1970s, remain in the environment and continue to reach hitherto pristine regions such as the Arctic and Antarctic. The overall goals of this RAPID project are to better understand the remobilization of POPs from melting glaciers in the Antarctic, and their transfer into the food-web. Legacy POPs have characteristic chemical signatures that will be used ascertain the origin of POPs in the Antarctic atmosphere and marine food-web. Samples that were collected in 2010 will be analyzed for a wide range of legacy POPs, and their behavior will be contrasted with results for emerging contaminants. The intellectual merit of the proposed research combines (a) the use of chemical signatures to assess whether melting glaciers are releasing legacy POPs back into the Antarctic marine ecosystem, and (b) a better understanding of the food-web dynamics of legacy POPs versus emerging organic pollutants.

The broader impacts of the proposed research project will include the training of the next generation of scientists through support for a graduate student and a postdoctoral scholar. As well, this work will result in a better understanding of the relationship between pollutants, trophic food web ecology and global climate change in the pristine Antarctic ecosystem.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many persistent organic pollutants (POPs), though banned in the U.S. since the 
1970s, remain in the environment and continue to reach hitherto pristine regions 
such as the Arctic and Antarctic. The overall goals of this RAPID project were to 
better understand the remobilization of POPs from melting glaciers in the Antarctic, 
and their transfer into the food-chain. Samples that were collected in 2010 were 
analyzed for a wide range of legacy POPs, and their behavior was contrasted with 
results for emerging contaminants. The intellectual merit of the proposed research 
combined (a) the use of chemical signatures to assess that melting glaciers were 
releasing legacy POPs back into the Antarctic marine ecosystem, and (b) a better 
understanding of the food-chain dynamics of legacy POPs versus emerging organic 
pollutants.
 The analysis of atmospheric samples showed the presence of a wide range of 
legacy (already banned) and emerging POPs in the Antarctic, albeit at very low 
concentrations. Typical gas-phase concentrations were around a pg m-3 
(10-12 g); only hexachlorobenze was present at around 30 pg m-3. Particle-
bound concentrations were generally lower than those in the gas-phase. The 
analysis of compounds in snow samples supported the theory that melting 
.glaciers are releasing legacy pollutants back to the Antarctic. Detected 
concentrations of the dissolved legacy pollutants in the glacier near Palmer 
station were significantly greater than concentrations detected at all the other
sampling sites. Unexpectedly, dissolved concentrations of polybrominated 
diphenylethers, a group of more recently banned flame retardants, were 
also significantly greater in the glacier sample than in all other snow samples. 
 A total of 80 blubber samples from three different seal species -  Lobodon 
carcinophagus (crabeater seal), Leptonychotes weddellii (Weddell seal) and 
Ommatophoca rossii (Ross seal) - and killer whales were analyzed for POPs. 
Significant differences emerged between the animals – killer whales displayed 
greatest concentrations, in-line with their highest trophic level. Detected 
concentrations of most POPs were significantly greater in adult males of  
Lobodon carcinophagus than concentrations in all age and sex groups of 
Ommatophoca rossii and Leptonychotes weddellii.  Presumably, the greater 
body burden of  the crabeater seals is linked to their wider migration pathways, 
allowing them to accumulate POPs from more contaminated regions as compared 
to the more localized feeding of the Antactic Ross and Weddell seal populations. 
The broader impacts of the proposed research project included: 
(a) the training of the next generation of scientists through support for a 
graduate student, Erin Markham, and a postdoctoral scholar, Dr. Mohammed 
Khairy. Erin Markham successfully defended her MS based on the science 
performed for this award at URI-GSO in 2014; 
(b) enabling graduate students from the Virginia Institute of Marine Science 
to finish the work and share their results through peer-reviewed publications. 
Several more publications are forthcoming resulting from this work; and 
(c) further exploring an existing set of samples for a better understanding of 
the distribution and origin of contaminants in the Antarctic. We were able to 
analyze almost 100 samples for a wide range of old and new pollutants, 
significantly adding to the understanding of pollutant dynamics in the 
Antarctic region.
